Hakyeon wanted far more than that, but it was something Leo was never to know—or perhaps it was better to say that he would know all too soon. He was used to seeing Leo hiding away from his responsibilities, shirking his duties, but here he was, performing them so admirably that one could never have guessed his sharp dislike for such things.

"We all have our places in the world," Hakyeon murmured quietly to himself. Just as Leo's was to rule, just as beasts were to be eaten, just as Hakyeon's was to be a murderer. In Leo's words.

He turned sharply on his heel, no longer caring about being unnoticeable. He would wait. Wait and hide. Until the guests had all gone, until Leo had returned to his chambers, until night had fallen and Leo's anguished screams would echo through the Keep the loudest.

And yet, as he tucked himself behind a pillar, steadying his breaths, it was the sound of harried footsteps, familiar footsteps, that approached. Hakyeon froze, still, unsure, and those five seconds of hesitation took the choice away from him.

"You're here."

Suddenly, Leo stood in front of him, and Hakyeon could not school his features into an appropriate expression fast enough, could not hide his moment of unintended delight at the small quirk of pleasure playing in Leo's eyes.

"As you well know," Hakyeon said. "We did speak earlier, did we not?"

"No," Leo said, grimacing a little in irritation, "I mean, you're here."

"Ah, you mean in this very spot? You're quite correct, as usual," Hakyeon said, purposely infuriating, and yet, Leo seemed not to rise to the bait. "How did you escape?"

"Ah." A slight flush crept at the tips of Leo's ears. "I said I had need of a private moment."

"Of course," Hakyeon said. "You are human after all, however much this might imply otherwise." He nodded towards the hall, encompassing the decorations, the people, and Leo's place in it all. It only seemed to fluster Leo further.

"I have to go," Leo said. "But..."

"Do finish your sentences," Hakyeon said. "It's very difficult to gather what you mean."

Finally, this netted Hakyeon a truly irritated scowl but it fell away far too quickly to be satisfying.

"I..." Leo paused, and his eyes shifted away from Hakyeon. Hakyeon waited, giving him space, giving him time. "I like talking to you," he finally said. "But there's nowhere to talk here. Can...my room?"

"Ah." Hakyeon blinked, smoothing down his heartbeat as best as he could, slipping a smile onto his face as best as he could. "Are you not afraid for your virtue?"

This time, Leo's ears turned bright pink, and Hakyeon couldn't quite hide a genuine smile. "Third floor," Leo said. "If you go to that door in the back, and then—"

"I believe I'll be able to find it," Hakyeon said, cutting him off. "Maybe you don't remember, but I've..."

It was Hakyeon's turn to trail off, unable to finish the sentence in its entirety. He watched Leo, unsure if he did remember, and if he hadn't, if it would jog his memory, and if it did—

"So it wasn't a dream," Leo said quietly.

"It is what you make of it," Hakyeon said. He inclined his head behind him, just a bit. "Perhaps you should go back."

Leo nodded. "I'll say I need to rest, later. My sister can take my place. She...used to do it a lot." A small smile played about Leo's lips, a memory, some sort of amusement that he felt like he did not need to conceal from Hakyeon. Hakyeon could acknowledge it as guilt, this feeling in his chest, this constriction, this sharp prickling like a bramble's thorns.

"Then I will find you when you do," Hakyeon said.

Leo nodded again, several small quick nods. A slight purse of his lips and then he was gone, leaving Hakyeon with a pounding heart and legs which seemed to no longer be able to hold his weight.

The stars were aligned, or so the saying went. Far too perfectly aligned.

 

☙⚔❧

 

"We're moving things up," Hakyeon said quietly to Jaehwan. To anyone watching, it would be an innocuous conversation—some member of a low ranked House conveying instructions to an attendant.

"What?" Jaehwan pulled back and frowned.

"He's planning on returning to his room," Hakyeon said. He saw the catch of surprise in Jaehwan's eyes—it would have been hard to miss.

"How do you know?" Jaehwan asked.

Hakyeon's smile was grim, if it could be called a smile. "He told me," he said. "He told me to meet him there."

Jaehwan's expression could only be labelled as incredulity. "He really does trust you," he said.

"Unfortunately." The word was out of Hakyeon's mouth before he could stop it, and it instantly drew a dark veil over Jaehwan's face. Hakyeon quickly shook his head. He'd seen Wonsik earlier in the peripheral of his vision, dressed as a simple server. He would be present if needed.

"I need you to keep an eye on the target's attendant," Hakyeon said, low and urgent. He had no clue where Hongbin was, and it worried him.

"As always," Jaehwan said, the verbal equivalent of rolling his eyes.

"Yes, well keep a better eye on him than usual," Hakyeon said. "The target may trust me, but that man..."

"Is very good at his job," Jaehwan finished for him. He nodded to somewhere behind Hakyeon. "That's your cue."

Leo had detached himself from the retinue and was withdrawing—not through the door that he had indicated to Hakyeon, but through another, far finer. So he knew that Hakyeon was not to be seen.

"Yes," Hakyeon said quietly. "Find Wonsik. Send him after me. I doubt I will need him, but it'll be the smarter choice."

Jaehwan took a step back and then sketched a bow to Hakyeon, form perfect. "Yes, my lord," he said.

Hakyeon nodded at him, a dismissal much like Leo had given him earlier. He watched as Jaehwan left, hopefully to seek out Hongbin, and prayed to the heavens above that all would go to plan. If that was how the whole praying thing worked—he'd never done it before.

He let the smallest hand of the clock travel about several rounds, the knife buckled inside his jacket a terrible weight. The glass bottle in his pocket was warm to the touch and Hakyeon could only hope that there was enough in it, and that it had been done right. Too much hinged on it, and this night would end very differently depending on the contents of this bottle. Hakyeon crossed his arms over his chest, letting his hands grip against his forearms, reassuring himself that the blades there were still strapped in well. Wonsik called him old fashioned, but Wonsik could keep his guns to himself—Hakyeon would keep his knives until the day he died.

The room seemed to fade away as Hakyeon slipped about its edges, the decorations blurring into every room that Hakyeon had ever been in, the people disappearing into an indistinguishable crowd. He waited a breath, and then another, and in the third—once he was sure that he would not be seen—he slipped through the door that Leo had indicated, and felt like his heart would burst.

These were not the servants' stairs. Hakyeon took quick stock of his surroundings. The steps were stone, the railings burnished steel. There was another door opposite the one he had come through, wooden and plain. The stairs up were to his left—there were no stairs to the cellar here, although the Keep must have had one. Perhaps through the other door—Hakyeon suspected it led to the servants' quarters. He sketched a quick layout of the place in his mind, placing what he knew and what Jaehwan had indicated to him onto one mental map.

The third floor, Leo had said, and Hakyeon remembered it well enough, at least from the outside. The Dragon's Keep was of a multi faceted design: twelve uneven sides forming an elongated sort of building. The hall was to one side, and from the placement of the doors, Hakyeon knew that he was at the back of the Keep. Leo's chambers were about halfway down, smaller than Hakyeon had expected, far more suited to a young child than the heir to the Seat. He would have to depend on all the activity in the Keep to be drawn to the ground floor—there would be very little space to hide. A small part of Hakyeon reminded him that he had a right to be here, that Leo had invited him up, and that were he to encounter someone, it would be enough to mention the purpose of his presence, and it could be confirmed soon enough by Leo himself. And yet.

Hakyeon removed the brooch about his throat, loosened his sleeves, unbuttoned his jacket, discarding the brooch in a small alcove behind the door. It no longer mattered how he appeared—any witnesses would have to be eliminated, and how effectively he could eliminate them was far more important. Hakyeon sank into himself, a calming breath even as his heart raced in an unfamiliar pattern. The sound of life was overwhelming from the other side of the door, and there was no movement that Hakyeon could hear from above.

The stairs opened into a hallway on the second floor and Hakyeon paused, unwilling to step beyond. Just as the Onyx Keep favoured dark stone and the Crimson Keep preferred walls and floors burnished with red, the Dragon's Keep had floors and walls of pale blue tinted stone. It felt too airy, too untouched for Hakyeon's taste, even knowing as he did that there was nothing pure about any part of this city, let alone this Keep.

The stairs continued to his right, but before Hakyeon had a chance to slip towards them, there was the quick sound of footsteps, too familiar to be of comfort, and Hakyeon swore.

"You—"

"Yes, me." Hakyeon stepped fully into the light to face Hongbin. "You and your master both seem to have an affinity for stating the obvious."

Hongbin was a cold ball of fury in front of him. His hand had gone to the hilt of his sword, the one he carried as was his right as Leo's attendant. Hakyeon looked at it, looked at Hongbin, and then looked at the stairs that continued upwards, to where Leo's chambers were.

"I don't want to fight you," Hakyeon said mildly. "My business isn't with you."

"His business is my business," Hongbin snarled.

"I really don't want to kill you," Hakyeon said. Nonetheless, he felt the weight of his knives reassuring against his arms.

"You'll have to if you want to get to him," Hongbin said.

Hakyeon inclined his head, an acknowledgement of his words. "Then you leave me with no choice," he said, and launched himself at Hongbin, snatching his knives from their sheaths as he did. Hongbin didn't flinch in the slightest, merely pulled out his own blade, easily countering both of Hakyeon's blows. Hakyeon danced back, out of Hongbin's considerably longer range. Blast it, what had Jaehwan been doing?

They watched each other warily, and Hakyeon knew that he had the advantage that Hongbin was unused to fighting for his life, merely only ever for play. Yet he suspected that would not be much of an advantage here, not with this man. He also doubted that he would truly be able to kill the man for the same reason he would never have been able to have killed Leo at first blow. There was real fear in Hongbin's eyes, but there was also desperation and fire and defiance and the true willingness to lay down his life.

He hoped it would not come to that.

Hakyeon made the first move—a feint forward, a step to the right. Hongbin fell for neither, lunging straight for Hakyeon, following it with a quick cut to the side that Hakyeon dodged, only for Hongbin to catch Hakyeon in the chest with his elbow. Hakyeon cursed silently, chest heaving with a need for air as he jumped back, putting space between them. Hakyeon was by no means short, but Hongbin was damned tall and Hakyeon's usual advantage of height was suddenly his disadvantage.

But there was no time. The sound of metal scraping against metal was the only warning Hakyeon got, his knife coming up before his mind caught up, Hongbin suddenly there, in front of him. Hakyeon snarled, shoving him off and ducking low, cutting under Hongbin's guard. The man swore as Hakyeon's blade caught at his leg, just enough to draw first blood. Hakyeon pulled back, far back, knowing it was too dangerous to push a man like Hongbin. The two of them faced each other, Hongbin breathing lightly, Hakyeon still trying to regain his breath from Hongbin's earlier blow.

Footsteps pounded up the stairs, two sets, and Hakyeon pivoted sharply, Hongbin doing the same. Friend or foe—relief or worse.

"You're here!" Jaehwan burst into view, followed shortly by Wonsik.

"Yes I am," Hakyeon snapped. "And so is he. What in hell were you doing?"

"I lost him, alright?" Jaehwan bared his teeth in irritation, but there were more pressing matters at hand. Jaehwan and Wonsik joined Hakyeon, flanking him on either side, spanning the width of the hall, facing Hongbin's solitary one. The fear was real now, but just as the fear grew, so did the fire.

"So there was a third one," Hongbin said. His eyes flickered briefly over Jaehwan to land on Wonsik, who merely shrugged and unholstered his gun.

"Don't know how much use I'll be—don't bring a gun to a knife fight, that still holds when you guys have swords, right?"

Jaehwan snorted, unsheathing his own blade. "Just don't shoot me and we'll be fine." He turned to Hakyeon. "Go! Before he gets tired of waiting!"

Hongbin cursed as he darted forward to block Hakyeon's path, but Jaehwan was closer and Hongbin's blade slid harmlessly off of Jaehwan's, even as Hakyeon ducked past Jaehwan to head up the stairs.

"Don't kill him," Hakyeon hissed as he pulled past. "Stop him, but don't kill him."

"Picky," Jaehwan muttered, but it was enough for Hakyeon to know that he'd heard. Enough for Hakyeon to bolt up the stairs with disregard, sheathing his blades as he did, the one still painted faintly with Hongbin's blood.

Hakyeon slowed at the last few steps. He tugged at his sleeves, buttoned his jacket. It would have to do. He walked with quick steps down the hall, still able to hear the faint sound of clashing metal behind him—there were no engines here to disguise the sound.

He encountered no one, a small mercy, and it was with far too quick a heartbeat that he stopped in front of Leo's door. Hakyeon thought of knocking—he grabbed the handle instead, the door swinging open easily when he twisted.

Leo was pacing uneasily inside, and when the door opened, he looked up, frozen, startled, before a small smile slipped unbidden onto his face.

"You came," he said.

Hakyeon snorted. "Yes, I appear to have," he said. He shut the door behind him, and it seemed too ominous a sound.

"I...wasn't sure," Leo said slowly, his eyes flickering away. "Perhaps it was too much of a request."

"Ah, were you thinking of more than simply...talking?" Hakyeon asked. Oh child, he wanted to say. He laughed instead, a small chuckle, a sound to fill the space rather than to convey amusement. "And to think that you said you would never enjoy my company."

"You're interesting," Leo said shortly. He still wasn't looking at Hakyeon and his ears had turned a bright red.

"And that is enough?" Hakyeon asked.

He took a step forward, but Leo had yet to meet his eyes, his gaze still directed off to the side like a bashful child. Like—

The realisation stopped Hakyeon in his tracks, a jagged dagger piercing through his chest and down to his gut. It twisted inside of him, the feeling sickening, nauseating, and Hakyeon found it suddenly difficult to breathe as he stared at the man in front of him—the target, the target—and the soft set of his lips, his eyes, his jaw.

Blast it all.

He closed the space between them in three quick steps and Leo looked up in surprise just in time for Hakyeon to catch his eyes widening before he pulled Leo to his chest, wrapping his arms about his waist, so warm, so sturdy. He pressed his hands flat against Leo's back, memorising the ridge of his shoulder blade, the dip in the small of his back. Leo was stiff in his embrace but he relaxed far too soon, far too willing to believe this lie that Hakyeon was presenting.

"I really wasn't dreaming," Leo said. His words were so soft and they brushed against the shell of Hakyeon's ear so near that it struck Hakyeon to his core.

"Perhaps you'll wish you had," Hakyeon said. He drew back slightly, meeting Leo's eyes. His hand came to rest on Leo's arm, and he gripped him, a shaking grasp.

"Why would—"

"I am sorry," Hakyeon said. Confusion was evident on Leo's face, but it was a confusion that Hakyeon could not himself face. In one quick motion, he drew the knife from within his jacket and crushed Leo to him again.

"You hold power, which makes you a powerful pawn," Hakyeon said—and slid the dagger into the space between Leo's ribs in one swift thrust.

It was done.

He stepped back, pulling the dagger out as he did so. Horror—no, something worse than that—filled Leo's eyes.

"My blade goes to the highest bidder," Hakyeon said softly. "But they are not your enemies—you have only ever been a means to the end."

The poison would act soon enough, but Hakyeon knew that at this moment, Leo's silence came not from the poison coated on the blade, but from within himself. "You were right. I did want something from you after all."

"My life," Leo said. His voice was already harsh, strained. Hakyeon inclined his head in agreement.

"Life is fragile—which makes you precious and treasured," Hakyeon said. He left before he could see Leo drop to the floor, the poison taking hold, but nothing could block out the screams as it filled Leo’s veins like fire.

Hakyeon ran. He slipped, crashing down the stairs, leg colliding painfully with the stone edge. His arm scraped against the railing, gashing it open, but Hakyeon ignored it as he turned the corner, all but throwing himself down the last flight.

Hongbin's look was one of pure horror.

"No—"

He lunged for Hakyeon, but he was bloody and bruised from Jaehwan and Wonsik, and it was all too easy a task for Hakyeon to grab him, clutch at his arms, stare into his fast reddening eyes.

"Listen to me," Hakyeon said urgently. He pressed the glass vial into Hongbin's hand. "Go. He's in his room. Now! His life depends on it!"

"What are you—"

"It's a mix of aconite and abrus eye, if this isn't enough—go now, if you love him as much as you do!" Hakyeon turned Hongbin about, pushed him towards the stairs, and finally, finally the man seemed to come to his senses, all but flying towards the room that Hakyeon had just left, towards Leo's horrible, horrible screams.

Jaehwan and Wonsik were both staring at him.

"We're done," Hakyeon said. "There's nothing more for us to do here."

"Hakyeon..."

"Some things are better left to chance," Hakyeon said.

Wonsik's eyes were too sharp on him, and Jaehwan's too pitying. Hakyeon pressed his lips together, then turned to stride down the hallway. "People will come soon," he said. "It's time for us to disappear."

"As we always do," Wonsik said.

"Perhaps we should disappear for longer this time," Jaehwan said.

Hakyeon laughed, short and bitter. Leo's screams rang loud through the building, and Hakyeon wanted nothing more than to block them out, to cover his ears and hide in a corner as a child might.

"Perhaps, this time, for good," he said—and then they were gone, leaving behind months of work to the hand of fate, and a piece of Hakyeon too shattered to name.

 

 

 

 

 

 

☙⚔❧

 

 

 

 

 

 

Winter blew in chill and stark, although without leaves to lose their colour and fall away there was little visible change beyond the silver frost in the mornings, the clouding of windows, the late rising of the sun, the early onset of darkness.

Taekwoon slipped into his room, latching the door shut behind him. The scar on his back ached, fine and thin though it was. It had been a near miss, the doctors had said. Half a touch to either side and the cut would have been fatal, regardless of his narrow escape from the poison. A great stroke of luck—a great touch of skill.

"I see you're at least alive."

Taekwoon turned slowly. He was lounging in the chair closest to the fire, hands folded in his lap, legs crossed, perfectly at ease. A small smile played at the corners of his mouth, especially as he stood, unfolding lanky limbs with all the grace of the cat.

"You said your blade went to the highest bidder," Taekwoon said.

The smile flickered wide only to disappear, leaving behind the truest sincerity that Taekwoon had ever seen on this man's face.

"There are some things more valuable than gold," the man said. He said this quietly, meaningfully, and his eyes never once wavered from Taekwoon's as he spoke. He stepped forward and Taekwoon twitched, but he did not move away, not even as the man had drawn so close that were he so inclined, he could again wrap his arms about Taekwoon, only to slide a blade into his back.

"You could at least ask my name," the man said, and the words skimmed against Taekwoon's cheek, followed by the soft brush of lips. "It's Hakyeon, by the way. What's yours?"

acknowledgements: influence from mistborn vol 1 (although it grew diluted as the story developed), many thanks to my dearest chingu and z for being sounding boards (many apologies to chingu for the breaking of suho's knees, despite bowing to your suggestion of making! taekwoon! sick! hmph), chingu for helping me fill out so much of this fic in terms of the world, jmm for getting me started as always despite not knowing a thing about vixx, shout out to everyone who kept me company writing, and thank you so much to tumblr user @hurtlucker for the beta despite the length!

happy holidays! i had a lot of fun writing this, and i hope that this...counts as a happy ending!

 

additional notes:
the city's structure was blatantly based off of the chinese 'four symbols' (although white->silver, black->onyx for word aesthetic reasons), and the chinese constellation system (x). which zodiac animals (again, some had to be replaced) were associated with which divine beast was arbitrary. constellations (星座) can be literally translated as 'star seat', where as an older name 星宿 can refer to them as 'mansions'. hence why they're 'seats', 'mansions', and 'houses' (because, well.) i did agonise a lot over this... similarly, all of the cities/states had names related to the sky... in case this wasn't obvious, ha... 'cardinal' comes from that each of the four beasts are related to a cardinal direction. (azure dragon of the east / spring, vermillion (crimson) phoenix of the south / summer, white (silver) tiger of the west / fall, black (onyx) tortoise of the north/winter)

 

(i have a rough map i will link to here when i scan it in)

 

even though lunenthal won't really have had pets for quite some time, i decided that 'puppy eyes' could still be a valid term—there's plenty of words/phrases in english that are based on things that no longer exist/origins have been forgotten! most recently, i learned that children no longer know that 'dialing a number' is because phones were once rotary phones... soliaire was roughly based off of east asia, i suppose...in terms of culture.

 

also, i love cats.

 

re: aconite/abrus eye berry...yes, i'm aware that neither of those work quite as described, especially timing wise. but i figure given the alternate development of the world, it's perfectly possible that there can be some reaction between the two that will cause the desired effects! (i also am aware that antidotes for such things don't quite work like that...alas.)

Work Text:

These days, Toya spent most of his time inside the flower shop, arranging bouquets and filling custom orders. It suited him.

The Akito that Toya had first met was brusque and a little rough around the edges, but the Akito that ran the flower shop was warm and polite and all smiles and meeting that Akito for the first time had been like meeting a stranger all over again. Toya envied him.

He wore a cap outside. Akito had snidely suggested dyeing his hair if he was so worried about it; and then he'd relented, reassuring him that it wasn't necessary. That he was safe. It didn't stop Toya from taking precautions.

He wasn't scared. Not for himself, at least. But after everything Akito had done for him, the guilt that he, Toya, could be the reason for destroying this idyllic life that the other man had carved out for himself–that, Toya couldn't handle.

A florist with connections, Toya had called him, all those months ago. Not knowing what those connections were was best for them all.

Akito was out when the woman came. It was a warm day, the sun slipping in and out of the clouds. Toya was debating stepping outside for a moment when the door opened.

"Welcome," Toya said.

She had short brown hair and an intense gaze that sized him up so quickly it made him uncomfortable. She was fashionably dressed, out-of-place in this small town end-of-the-road flower shop. She belonged in a city, with her brisk movements and stern face. She swept her gaze over the small space, and then landed back on Toya.

Can I help you find anything?--but he never got to say that.

"Where's Akito?" she asked. Blunt. Curt. Accusatory, instead of a question.

Toya swallowed. "He will be back soon," he said. She didn't seem to like that answer. Toya glanced past her, out the window, willing Akito to appear.

Wait. Why was she here? Who was she? Was she dangerous?

"May I ask why you're looking for him?" Toya followed with. "Can I help you instead?"

"I'm his sister," the woman said, narrowing her eyes. "You're Toya. I know about you. Akito's told me enough."

His sister? Akito had never said anything about a sister. But Akito had never really talked about his family. Other than that first day, neither of them ever mentioned family. Toya didn't know anything about Akito. How much could Akito have told this woman, his sister, if she was telling the truth? They didn't look too alike. Her hair was brown while Akito's was orange; her eyes a similar shade while Akito's was a warm sage.

“You don't believe me?" she asked, raising an eyebrow. "Well. This is important. I need to talk to him."

"Would you like to sit as you wait?" Toya pulled out the stool from behind the counter and offered it to her. It seemed to catch her off guard, and for a moment, Toya could see the similarity between her and Akito. Where Akito wore a mask of sunshine, his sister wore one of glass.

"I don't need it," she said, words short and clipped. "This will be short."

Toya nodded. "Akito will be back soon," he repeated.

"You said that," she said, eyes narrowing slightly in irritation.

"I… Ah–"

The bell above the door rang as it opened, cutting Toya off.

"Sorry Toya, they were out of… Ena!? What… why… What are you…"

The door shut behind Akito like a slow motion film, the edge caught on his sleeve as he froze in the entryway. His eyes flickered towards Toya and for the first time since they'd met, there was something there that he'd never seen before in Akito, but often enough at the other end of his gun. Fear.

As if sensing Toya's sudden wariness, Akito grimaced, schooling his face into one of neutrality. But his fingers gripped the paper sandwich bag so tightly the paper began to crumple and tear. Toya hurried across the small space to take it, almost having to pry it from Akito's fingers.

"I'll go outside," Toya said softly.

"No, this involves you," Akito's sister said at the same time Akito nodded, his eyes never leaving his sister.

A chill ran down Toya's spine like cold rain, setting and pooling heavily in his gut. It… involved him?

He met Akito's eyes, and saw his apprehension mirrored there.

"If this is family business, Toya has nothing to do with it," Akito said.

"But he seems to have plenty to do with you," Ena said cooly. Toya resisted the urge to grab Akito's hand, to smooth out the tension in his clenched fist.

Akito had gone quiet. And very, very still.

"You want me to go back," Akito said.

For some reason, annoyance flashed across his sister's face. "Mizuki was right," she muttered. "But not quite. Akito. I'll be brief. Father wants you back. And it's an order."

"Ena–"

"No buts."

"You're the one who said I'd lost enough!" Akito yelled. Toya flinched–he'd never heard Akito raise his voice like that before. His sister, however, didn't waver.

"You've had your break, and it looks like you've enjoyed it," she said. "You have a week."

"No. I refuse."

Ena waved a hand dismissively. "That's not an option."

"What're you gonna do, drag me out of here?"

"Of course not, and I won't need to." Her attention suddenly swung towards Toya. "I haven't introduced myself. Shinonome Ena. Akito's older sister. And it's just the two of us, when it comes to siblings."

"... Shinonome?" Toya repeated slowly. He looked to Akito, but Akito was staring at the ground.

"I figured he hadn't told you," Ena said. "That's right. He's the only son of the Shinonome family."

"Akito? Is that true?"

"Why wouldn't it be?" Ena said.

"Please let Akito speak for himself," Toya said. Ena, taken aback, fell silent.

Akito visibly swallowed, and without looking at Toya, said a soft "yeah, never seemed relevant so didn't mention it."

Toya was brimming with questions, but they were ones he didn't want Akito to answer with his sister here. It felt very, very relevant.

"I see," Toya said.

"A week," Ena said, breaking the silence that fell after Toya's words. "Akito, did you hear me? I'm not any happier about this than you are. And I'm not going to pretend that this is fair to any of us, but none of us have a choice. I know… I meant it when I said you'd suffered enough. But I guess I wasn't good enough for him."

Bitterness. There was so much bitterness there. And she seemed to care for Akito, under that glass mask of hers. So much history. So much of Akito he didn't know about.

"I refuse," Akito repeated, but it was weaker this time. "You can't make me."

"No, but he can," Ena said, and from the way Ena's eyes flickered to Toya as she spoke, he suddenly understood what she'd meant by this involves you.

"Leave Toya out of this!" Akito took a step towards his sister, almost growling.

"That'll be up to you," she said.

And then she was gone.

The two men stood there in a frozen tableau, each barely bearing to breathe, each for their own reasons. It was Toya who moved first - to reach past Akito and turn the sign of the shop to read CLOSED.

He still held the sandwiches Akito had picked up for lunch on the way back from his delivery. His head spun, questions and answers and premonitions and dread swirling in a dark, endless vortex. It threatened to swallow him.

And it was close to swallowing Akito.

Toya touched him on the shoulder. "Akito?"

Akito startled like he'd just noticed him there. There was pain there, pain and fear and anguish, but it was the lack of something that gave Toya pause.

Still:

"Let's go home for lunch," Toya said. "It will be fine to close up early for one day."

"Just one day?" Akito said, and this time, bitterness seeped out through his words. He frowned, shook his head. Opened the door. Toya locked it.

They walked back in silence, side by side. They hadn't needed to bring anything this morning, so they'd left Akito's car behind.

Toya carried the sandwiches. His other hand hung loosely by his side, even though instinct would have him reaching for Akito. There was a cloud around the other man that made him untouchable. There were times, Toya had learned over these few months, that Akito needed space.

He'd also learned that it would fade, with time. Minutes, hours, days.

Today, the door had just shut behind them when Akito said:

"I guess we should talk."

"We can wait until–"

"Don't bother," Akito said brusquely as he kicked off his shoes, tossing the words over his shoulder. "You've got questions. Just ask."

Toya considered this as he undid the laces on his own sneakers and lined both pairs neatly against the entryway.

"Should we eat first?" Toya asked, already expecting the shake of Akito's head.

"Not a real question. Not hungry right now. You can eat if you want."

Toya just nodded, and put the sandwiches in the fridge. He didn't know when they'd be eating.

Questions.

He had so many questions.

Why did you not think it was relevant?

"What were those calls you made?"

Akito startled, his back stiffening where he still stood in the living room.

"What calls?" he said, and then, in the defeated tone from earlier: "surprised you didn't ask earlier."

He felt Toya approach him, and then hover behind him. It was strange how quickly Akito had come to trust the other man. They'd met each other mere months ago, but he felt like someone he'd always known.

"Was it your sister?" Toya asked.

"Yeah. Ena was one of 'em. I… I owe her a lot." It was a bitter admission. How he'd always resented her for having the childhood he'd never had. How he'd always thought that her help was the least she could do. She hadn't needed to.

But she also hadn't needed to threaten Toya.

A plan was beginning to formulate in his mind, and Akito whirled about to come face to face with Toya, a slight frown on his usually expressionless face.

"Please calm down," Toya said.

Akito balked. He hadn't said a word yet.

"You're thinking about something reckless," Toya said. He closed the distance between them, and Akito let himself fall against him, let his head rest against Toya's shoulder. They stood like that for several heartbeats before Toya touched Akito's cheek, gently guiding his head upright. Toya's bangs fell gently over his grey eyes, and Akito brushed them away by reflex. With the same care Toya did everything with, he caught Akito in a tender kiss.

You really are from that world, Akito had said that first time.

Quieter now, calmer now, and with a deliberateness he'd learned in the past few months overtaking the brusque utility and forced tenderness the years before had trained into him.

Please calm down, Toya had said, and every touch echoed his words. It felt easy, safe, and Akito selfishly fell into this false sense of safety. Easier to let Toya move them into the bedroom in small, gradual steps, slowly, as if guiding a skittish cat. He never let go of Akito for a second, and Akito leaned into that touch–his lips, his hands, his fingers. It wasn't until Toya had gently lowered Akito onto the bed that he released that tenuous connection, as if waiting until he was sure that Akito was safe and grounded.

"Toya," Akito murmured into the space between their lips as Toya drew back.

"Akito?"

"I've calmed down," he said. Toya gazed at him steadily for a few moments, and then without saying a word, picked up Akito's hand and pressed it against his chest. Toya's answer was the hammering of Akito's heart.

A strange, half-smothered laugh bubbled up in Akito's throat, his eyes falling closed. All he'd wanted was to sit in peace among his sunflowers, but it was something life would deny him.

Toya's weight blanketed him, his lips pressing soft kisses down Akito's neck. His hands smoothed up Akito's stomach, his chest, pushing his shirt up as he caressed his skin. Akito pushed up into that touch, reaching instinctively for Toya's hand, his fingers closing around the delicate wrist, guiding Toya lower, lower, lower, the pads of Toya's fingers trailing against his skin. He let out a sharp gasp when Toya took over, palm splayed against Akito's hip, pushing down the waistband of his pants.

"Shh," Toya murmured against Akito's shoulder. "It will be alright."

He let out a shuddering breath, weight sinking into the bed. Behind his closed eyelids, he seemed to see Toya pull away, only the lingering phantom touch of his weight and warmth remaining against Akito's chest. He seemed to see Toya briefly catch his lip between his teeth as he gazed down at him. Felt his weight shift, and he opened his eyes to Toya's clear, grey ones.

"You'll be alright," Toya said, fingers brushing Akito's cheek. He was gentle as he undressed Akito, his hands roaming across Akito's bare body, every touch echoing his words.

He wanted to believe him.

If Toya was from that world, then what was he?

Toya's soft lips had just touched Akito's cock when Akito pushed Toya off as he surged upright.

"Akito?" Toya's tongue wet his lips, his brows creased.

"No."

He flipped their positions, slid down the side of the bed, pulling Toya to the edge. Toya's eyes flickered in understanding. His fingers tangled in Akito's hair, tugging gently at his scalp. Akito undid the fasteners of Toya's pants, dragging them down along with his underwear.

"Please. Toya, please." Akito breathed against Toya's stomach, straining away from Toya's grasp. He licked down the tangle of hair, rough against his tongue.

Toya guided Akito lower, fingers tracing the line of Akito's jaw. Akito needed no prompting to take in all of Toya at once, and it was all Toya gasped, almost undone right then and there. But Akito needed right now. Toya carded his fingers through his hair, a gentle motion, before he thrust roughly into Akito's mouth.

Akito nearly gagged as Toya's cock hit the back of his throat, causing Toya to still. Akito squeezed Toya's arm in irritation, glaring up at him as best as he could. And Toya always tried his best to be helpful.

Akito clung to Toya as Toya fucked relentlessly into his mouth, down his throat. It felt easy to let his mind fall slack as he let his throat fall slack, the taste of Toya on the back of his tongue a faint, fuzzy warmth. His eyelids fluttered shut, world narrowing down to his hand on Toya's thigh, Toya's fingers in his hair, and Toya's cock in his mouth.

"Good boy," Toya praised Akito. It sent the warmth that'd been slowly growing inside Akito into a frenzy, firing through his limbs and his own cock. Akito groaned, reaching down to touch himself.

He stroked himself in time to Toya's rhythm. Every time Toya fucked into his mouth. It was so easy to let go like this.

Easy. Safe.

It was over too soon. Toya's soft touch against Akito's jaw was a warning that pulled Akito back into his own body, just enough to swallow Toya's come, his throat constricting around Toya's cock. He forced his eyes open and gazed upwards with heavy eyelids; Toya's composure undone, his parted lips, the rapid rise and fall of his chest, his eyes still slightly glazed as he looked down at Akito.

Toya pulled Akito back onto the bed with him. "You shouldn't do that to your knees," Toya's voice echoed in Akito's mind–he'd tripped the other day and crashed down onto the flagstones, but the bruises had all but faded already. Toya was still fussing over it.

Still, it was nice to lean back against Toya's chest, their bodies pressed together. Toya's fingers joined Akito's around his hard cock.

It didn't take much for Akito to completely let go.

Toya held Akito close, wrapping his arms around Akito's chest. He wasn't sure when Toya had shed his shirt, but it was nice to be pressed against him, skin to skin, heartbeat to heartbeat, breath to breath.

But the morning, the past few hours, suddenly bared its claws, talons tearing through the web of safety.

Akito exhaled deeply, extracting himself from Toya's embrace. He rolled over onto his back.

And found he didn't know what to say.

Toya was torn between gathering Akito back to him, and letting Akito take the lead. He found Akito's hand, interlacing their fingers.

Questions. He'd had questions to ask. There was so much about Akito he didn't know–so much that Akito didn't want to know himself. But now, Toya could sense that those answers were ones Akito was ready to give. Toya didn't know what the right questions were to ask. His eyes traced the firm line of Akito's muscled body, lean, but well toned with physical activity. It wasn't just from carrying bags of soil, though. Akito preferred to practice in private, and Toya had learned when he should take longer walks.

"When did you learn to fight?" Toya asked.

There was a question behind the question that kept Akito from looking away from the ceiling.

"After," he said, and there was no need for Toya to ask after what?. Akito grimaced, the memory bitter. "Not that it'd have done much good before."

"You were young," Toya said.

"Or I'd never have believed them," Akito said. Toya's gaze was quizzical, but this was something Akito didn't want to explain. He turned to Toya, met his eyes. "But I'd run, I said so, damn the consequences."

Toya found his hand and squeezed.

"You said you didn't think it was relevant," Toya said. By all accounts, Toya was calm, unfazed, but just as Toya had learned to read behind Akito's brusque exterior, Akito had learned that Toya chose his words carefully. When he could. When it mattered. But here, now, they came fragmented and piecemeal.

"It shouldn't have been," Akito said. "It wasn't supposed to have been."

Toya nodded, his expression solemn.

"Your sister is the reason you have the shop. You shouldn't be angry at her." A pause. "You also shouldn't be angry at yourself."

"Why'd I be pissed at myself?" Akito snapped, at the same moment he realised that yeah, just a bit, he might've been. Not for taking in Toya. Never for that. But for believing it wasn't relevant. That'd been fucking stupid of him. He exhaled deeply. Turned back to stare at the ceiling. "Doesn't matter anyway. Don't even wanna think why Dad wants to see me."

"Then I will—"

"You won't do a fucking thing," Akito ground out. He sat up, stared down at Toya, who looked back at him with the same steady expression as always.

He too sat up, and Akito noticed that their hands were still interlinked, that Toya's hand was clamped between his fingers like a vice, that it was almost like Akito had pulled Toya up with the sheer force of that single connection. But he didn't let go.

"Akito," Toya said, and something in Akito faltered, hearing his name spoken like that. Like he mattered. Like he cared. "If I leave now, then it will not matter if your sister reveals my location."

"You can't be that fucking naive," Akito said, voice low, his eyes fixed on their hands. A pianist's fingers, he'd thought, when he'd first met Toya. He didn't play piano. He should've. "Dad'll come up with something else. Burn down the shop or something. No, we both go."

"Go where?" Toya asked.

"I dunno, wherever you were gonna go," Akito snapped. They both knew that Toya didn't have anywhere to run either. Akito sighed, dragged a hand down his face. Fuck. Would've been easier to do this while reckless. What'd his half-formed idea been anyway? Leave, let Toya take over the shop? Then what, leave him at his family's mercy? Should've been to send Toya away in that case. But no, he couldn't do that. Wouldn't help. They'd both go. Go where? was the question.

"She gave us a week," Toya gently reminded him. "We should think this through calmly."

"Like you're calm?" Akito said, more cutting than he meant, and was rewarded by a small hitch in Toya's shoulders, as if he were flinching away from his words. "No. Don't… you're right. Dammit, but you're right. Ena's not stupid. If I don't show up, dad'll blame her. She's gonna be keeping an eye on us. Or someone is. How the fuck am I supposed to be calm? What the fuck am I supposed to do?"

He felt the despair climbing up his spine again, filling his lungs.

"Akito?" Toya's voice prodded at his consciousness, and Akito blinked as he mentally grabbed onto it like a life ring.

"Yeah?"

"What if… Have you considered agreeing to your sister's request?" Toya said.

" 'course I have," Akito said. He paused.

"You haven't," Toya said, before Akito could continue. "You've considered why you do not wish to see the head of the Shinonome family, but haven't considered all the possibilities of a meeting with your family."

"I barely remember 'em," Akito said, and it wasn't quite a lie. "Never saw my dad much anyway. Dunno what happened to mom. Not much of a family. Kinda fucked up, not that I'd know what it's supposed to be like."

He stopped, words frozen. But Toya hadn't reacted. Probably didn't want to talk about it. Hell, forget about Toya's family, Akito had never asked him his family name. Hadn't seemed relevant, just like his own hadn't seemed relevant. Shouldn't have been.

"What would be the worst outcome?" Toya asked, prodding him back into the present.

"I…" To rejoin the family? To give up the shop? To… "Nothing good," Akito settled with.

"I understand," Toya said. Impossible, because not even Akito understood what he himself was thinking.

"Understand what?" Akito asked wryly.

"That you are calmer now, and we can think about it before acting recklessly. Would you like me to make some coffee? I can also try to make pancakes–"

The last word was barely out of Toya's mouth before Akito nearly flung himself out of bed.

"No, absolutely not. I'm making the pancakes, you're not touching the stove. Have you forgotten what happened last time? What're you laughing at!?"

Toya was laughing in that small, quiet way of his. He shook his head, like it was a secret for himself. "Please put on pants before leaving the room, the living room window is open," was all Toya said, before getting off the bed himself.

—

It was after the pancakes, the sandwiches abandoned in the fridge, after the coffee, and after the 'leftover' pancakes, that Akito went to sit in the garden while Toya insisted on washing the batter bowl and the dishes.

There was a table between two patches of sunflowers. It wasn't too far from where he'd first seen Toya, when he'd thought him beautiful, injured, and afraid. Mere months ago, he reminded himself. Barely any time ago. A boy drenched in blood, falling into his life, shortly after daybreak. Why'd he hide him, help him? Because he was beautiful? Because he felt bad? Because Toya reminded him of himself?

"To kill someone… what's that like?"

Toya paused behind him, a hesitation.

"Ugh, don't answer that–"

"Are you saying that because you don't want to know the answer, or because you don't want me to have to answer?" Toya asked. He lingered for a moment by Akito's shoulder before walking past him, taking the other seat.

Akito looked down at the table. Dirt seemed to be embedded in the crevices. He ought to wash that off.

"I… don't mind," Toya said hesitantly. "I asked you many uncomfortable things as well."

"Yeah, but that doesn't mean you have to," Akito said.

"Ah, so it was the second," Toya said.

Akito exhaled, glanced at the flowers, and nodded.

And then: silence.

Toya was staring at the flowers. He spent more time in the greenhouse–the garden was still Akito's. They were unfamiliar to Toya in a way the greenhouse flowers weren't. It was a hollow feeling; the thought of leaving them behind.

There was a blankness in Toya's eyes that frightened him. As if he'd dove so far back in his memories that he was lost to the present.

"If you hadn't stopped me… I think I would have been like her."

"Huh…?"

"I… don't know if I could have done it, if she hadn't…" Toya swallowed, closed his eyes. His voice, always quiet, dropped to barely above a whisper. "... hadn't begged me to kill her. If you hadn't stopped me from going back, I think I would have been like her."

What do you mean? The question stuck to the roof of his mouth, choking him. But Toya continued anyway, halting, hesitant, stumbling–but persistent.

"You said, that day, that world was all I had ever known. Then you know that I thought it was the only thing I could do, that it meant I was one of the lucky ones. I knew there was another world, and sometimes the older kids would speak of it longingly, but some of them said it was a terrible place. That they liked being safe, not being hungry, not being scared of dying. There were monsters outside. Before that, I didn't know what that was like… being scared of dying. But when they put the gun in my hands, I understood–that I was scared of dying, but she was scared of living.

" I… don't remember what happened after that, but it was probably like you said, Akito. Sometimes it hurt, but as long as I did what they told me… it was home. I had to go home. It was bad of me, because I knew they were afraid but I still did it. Killed them. Ah, but you asked what it was like. I… I don't know. I'm sorry, Akito, I never thought about that before."

"Fuck, that's…“

Akito had sat there, frozen, as Toya spoke. What was he supposed to say? Was he supposed to say anything? But the beat of silence after Toya's last words dragged those two words out of him before he could stop them. Toya looked at him quizzically, and Akito shook his head out of habit.

"It's what?" Toya asked.

"Fucked up. That's fucked up. Fuck. You shouldn't have… that shouldn't have happened."

"Is it not the same everywhere?" Toya's question was too nonchalant. Too matter-of-fact. "Does the Shinonome family not do the same thing?"

"Fuck no! Not… Not like that," Akito said. "I mean… we… it's not… but it's not much better. Don't wanna fucking think about it. I want nothing to do with it, none of it."

"That is why you do not wish to see your family?" It was a question, but the way Toya said it, it meant he already knew that Akito would answer with a silent nod.

"Can we… can we sleep for tonight?" Akito asked, not quite meeting Toya's eyes.

Toya kissed the top of Akito's head and held him tight for a moment before he said "yes, please".

 

—----

 

Akito woke in a daze–the panic of an empty bed clamped him a moment later.

"Toya?" He sat up slowly, feeling the gaping space beside him. His heart only started beating again when his fingers landed on a sheet of paper, left prominently on the pillow.

"Fuck, you scared me," Akito breathed as he read Toya's neat handwriting.

I left for a walk.
I didn't want to wake you.

He crumpled the note and shoved it in his pocket. No telling when he'd be back like this. He would be back, Akito was sure of it. Toya wasn't the type to go back on his word.

Didn't blame him for the walk, though. Toya probably needed to clear his head as bad as Akito did. He'd also developed a tendency to vanish when Akito needed to be alone. No idea how Toya'd figured that out, but he was thankful for it.

He was halfway through his morning routine before the futility of it suddenly struck him.

It'd become abundantly clear that the shop would be closed for more than just one day. He glanced at the greenhouse with its neat, flower filled shelves. His eyes lingered on the pile of straw he'd shoved Toya under that first day. That straw was long gone. Would've been by now, even if he hadn't trashed it because of the blood. He shook his head, dispelling the memory of panic. The flowers looked good. As long as the sprinklers kept working, some might survive. For what? What was the point?

Akito sighed, turning his back on its glass walls.

Toya would be a while. Might as well water his garden. Not like he had anything better to do.

It was eerily similar. A black car pulling up. Two men getting out. Intimidating.

No Toya this time, though.

Akito straightened, putting down the watering can.

"Can I help you gentlemen?" he asked, his eyes narrowing. They weren't the same guys. But they were bad news. On top of everything else, he didn't need to deal with a Thing One and Thing Two. Thug One and Thug Two.

"Cut the crap. We know he's here."

"Who're you?" Akito crossed his arms, glowering at them. They were both taller than him. Maybe even taller than Toya.

"Shut up and step aside," Thug One said, taking a step towards him.

"Get your ugly mugs outta here before I call the cops," Akito said. He refused to move.

"Ha. The cops? You think we're scared of the cops? You're going to call the cops when he's here?"

He?

They were here for Toya…?

At a time like this?

He narrowed his eyes. "I dunno what you're talking about, but if you don't get the fuck out of here, you're trespassing."

Dammit, he should've insisted on getting Toya a phone–could warn him not to come back. At least he wasn't here right now.

Ena wouldn't break her word, but he wouldn't put it past his dad.

"Who the fuck are you to him anyway? Is he that good in bed?"

Akito lunged forward at Thug Two, snarling. "You take that back!"

His punch landed with a satisfying crunch, but that was all he got before he doubled over from Thug One driving his fist into his stomach, his vision momentarily blacking out as all the air left his body.

"So he is here, that blue haired brat," Akito heard, through the fog in his head. "Shot up our office and thought he'd get away with it. It's early. Check the bedroom."

Akito staggered to his feet. Too late, the other guy was already slamming open the unlocked door.

He had to get them out before Toya came back.

"It's too late, he's gone!" Akito yelled. He didn't get far. A well placed elbow against his back had him crumpling to the ground. His hands dug into fertile soil, and he felt flowers crunch under his face.

Shit. He couldn't stay down like this.

He swung his arm at the guy's ankles, catching him off guard enough to make him stumble. It gave Akito enough time to get back to his feet. Spared a look for his garden–trampled.

"He's not here," Akito repeated. "So get the fuck out."

He was better prepared this time and blocked the punch. Guy hit like a truck.

"Don't try us, brat. That Shinonome chick was here yesterday. We know you're hiding him."

That Shinonome chick? Ena. They were talking about Ena. But that meant… they didn't know she was his sister. They didn't know he was the Shinonome son.

"Yeah? So that's who she was?" Akito spared a glance behind him. He didn't like the sounds coming from his house. Was gonna be a pain to clean. He kept a wary eye on the guy in front of him, settling into a fighting stance. Still hurt to breathe. He had to get them out of here. And then he could worry about his garden.

"Man, you really don't know," he said. "Took him in because he's got a pretty face?"

"Shut the fuck up," Akito growled. He didn't repeat his mistake and swallowed his anger deep into his chest this time. "And I told you. He's gone. He's left."

"Oi, any luck?" Thug One yelled.

"Nothing," Two said, spitting in disgust. Akito warily shifted his position, trying to keep an eye on both of them at the same time.

"I told you. He left. He's gone," he said.

Wait. Toya's note.

"He left during the night," Akito quickly added. "He left a note."

He reached into his pocket for the crumpled sheet of paper, feeling for the torn edge. Carefully, he ripped it blindly in two. He couldn't fuck up here. They were watching him like a hawk with a mouse.

"I told you. He left." He held out what he hoped was the correct half.

Two, clearly the more junior of the pair, snatched it from Akito's hand. He read it, frowned, and then nodded at the other guy.

"Might've faked it," One said.

"It's not. He's gone. Left during the night. If you get out now I won't call the cops. Or do you want breaking and entering and property damage on top of trespassing?" Akito bared his teeth, staring them down. "Fucking pieces of shit," he spat out.

A third voice jerked at his attention like a barbed fish hook. He hadn't noticed there was someone else in the car. "Someone's coming!" a man yelled through the car window.

"Right. Bring him with us," One said.

At least they were leaving before Toya got back, was his last conscious thought.

 

- - -

 

There was an unfamiliar car.

Toya pulled up short, senses firing into alarm.

Something was very, very wrong.

Akito wasn't in the yard. There was no sign of Akito. Toya had instinctively ducked off the road and approached the house from the back. There were clear signs of a scuffle. Multiple people. Dirt marked by footprints.

He didn't have time to look further, not when an unfamiliar voice sounded out calmly behind him. "Hello there," the stranger said. He had a gun.

Toya pivoted, instinctively ducking and jabbing upwards. Only to catch empty air. He hopped back, throwing up his guard.

"Woah, easy there, we're on the same side," the stranger said, who'd stepped back, hands in the air. His hair was a striking shade of purple. He smiled wryly at Toya's wary look, then casually spun the gun in his hand before slipping it into his back pocket.

"Toya, right? Shinonome had me keeping an eye on the two of you–"

"What did you do to Akito?" Toya asked, voice icy.

"I did nothing," the purple haired stranger said, lips twisting into the semblance of a smile in response to some private joke. "Which is part of the problem, quite unfortunately. You see, we hadn't considered something like this and he was sleeping quite soundly when you abruptly left. So, I followed you."

Toya straightened, sensing the truth in this strange man's words. "Akito's sister told you to watch us," he said.

"Something like that. Like the kid said, Shinonome the elder would've blamed her if the two of you vanished."

"You were listening," Toya said. 'The kid' must've meant Akito. This man was older than them.

"I was, which is also how I know that the kid's abductors don't know who he is, and it sounds like they have a grudge against you. Mind, I got here not long before you did. It seems like someone else scared them off. Three of them, I believe. Now, I suggest we take a look at the damage those hooligans did, and perhaps sit down inside and discuss our plans."

"I don't know what your plan is, but I will find Akito," Toya said, hands balling into fists. This man was too calm.

"As I said, we're on the same side here. There will be some very upset people if anything happens to Shinonome Junior and we want to prevent that, hm? Please, lead the way, you're the one after all who lives here, not me." He gestured at Toya, nodding towards the house.

That Toya lived in, yes, but only because Akito had taken him in.

Swallowing his suspicions and discomfort, Toya obeyed. If this man was working for Akito's sister and father, then as much as Toya was loathe to admit, he had more resources than Toya could imagine. Akito could berate him after for accepting this man's help, because it put him in further debt to his family and that was the opposite of what he wanted. But first, he needed Akito back. Safe. Realistically, working with this man was his best chance.

The house was a mess. It didn't surprise him. The man had clearly been listening in, and he'd mentioned 'the damage'. Toya was acutely aware of the stranger's presence, not that he was making any effort to be scarce.

"The kid has a good eye," the stranger commented, eyeing the trashed decor.

Toya glanced at him as he righted the furniture. "You haven't told me your name," Toya said, much too bluntly. He swallowed the urge to apologise, to reword his question.

"Ah, you're right. You can call me Rui, Toya-kun. You're much more polite than the kid–"

"Akito. His name is Akito."

"Right, right." Rui waved a hand dismissively. "More than Akito. You do know that you're the only one that calls him that outside of his sister? No, of course not, how silly of me. That's unimportant. Now, can you think of anyone who has a bone or two to pick with you? Perhaps someone whose office 'you shot up', I believe were their words?"

Toya's blood ran cold. Not because he couldn't think of anyone, but because… "There are a few. I… don't remember."

Rui quirked an eyebrow. "Ah, right, I did hear you were quite efficient. Nonetheless, if you could give me a list, the two of us should be able to narrow it down between us. Most recent first, if you'd please." He snagged the pile of sticky notes that Toya and Akito kept on the fridge to jot down grocery needs, and slid it towards Toya on the now righted table, producing a pen from somewhere within his own pockets.

With a jolt, Toya realised that this strange man was doing for him much like he'd tried with Akito the night before. Calm him down. Think things through. He was right, of course–what hope did either of them have to chase blindly after a car that could've gone anywhere by now?

Rui had taken a thin tablet out from some inner pocket, and was scrolling through it with one long finger, making a call at the same time. It went through an earpiece, so Toya had no chance of overhearing the other end.

"Ah, Mizuki, good. Yes, an emergency I'm afraid. Just you, if you don't mind, I'll send over a list. Hm, I believe the two of us will suffice, but if you wish to meet us there–where? That is… ah, perfect, thank you Toya–" Rui paused to skim the list that Toya wordlessly passed over. He'd narrowed it down to three that seemed most likely, and one of them must've been a hit by the way Rui's eyes lit up. "Yes, I'll send it now, and then we'll be on our way, hopefully before they rough up Junior any further. A message? Of course. Take care, Mizuki."

He'd barely hung up when he turned to Toya, his eyes narrow and appraising. "The message is for you," he said. A pause, during which their eyes met, and Toya was caught off-guard by a flash of deep solemnity, like glimpsing the bottom of an ancient lake. A smile played about Rui's lips, like he was laughing at a private joke. "The words were 'thanks for taking care of li'l bro'--as I said, you are the only other person to call him 'Akito'."

Toya was about to protest, because everyone in their life called him Akito, because that was his name, but this stranger was not from their life (and it was with a jolt that he thought 'our' life), but from one Akito had lived long before these few idyllic months. And it was from that one, Toya was soberly reminded, from which their present situation arose.

"You seem to have determined where Akito is," Toya said, filing the message from 'Mizuki' for later. Akito's sister had mentioned them, he was sure of it.

If Toya's bluntness surprised Rui, he didn't show it.

"With your help, I have a good idea," Rui said.

"Then let's go–"

"Ahh, but an idea is not the same as knowledge," Rui said, cutting him off. "I understand your eagerness and I appreciate the urgency, yet what good would it do to run a mile west when we should have gone a mile east, except to run three miles when a third of that would have done? You're a rather level-headed boy, and that will prove to be much more helpful here than Junior's rashness. I have some information here, and here," Rui tapped his tablet and then his temple in succession, "but it pales to the database back at headquarters, and that, I believe, is what will allow us to surprise the kid's captors. After all, I have no doubt that they intend you to find them, or their bait would serve no purpose. But it is difficult to say what will happen in the interim, or how long that would take. Regardless, I have placed some more… visual surveillance in the surrounding area, so if the criminals return to the scene of the crime, and I believe they will, we'll be well apprised."

Rui regarded Toya coolly as he spoke. He'd been a tad surprised to find the boy so hot-headed when his prior knowledge, as limited as it was, spoke to a quiet and calculating man that understood the importance of action with purpose, rather than pure emotion. Something that kid could've stood to learn. Perhaps it would've kept him from getting himself kidnapped and saved them all this headache and trouble. Rui thought of himself as a rather unflappable person himself, but even he feared Ena's reaction once she inevitably learned of his failure. Ah well, he was a decent shot but no sniper, and even if he'd been sufficiently close, was certainly no good in close combat. Fighting… wasn't exactly his specialty. And what was done was done. No, he needed the back-up, and it reassured him that the back-up and underlying cause for this headache had begun to breathe again.

Good.

"You only had audio inside the house," Toya said, after a moment.

"I didn't have much to work with," Rui admitted, "and I did consider your… privacy."

Toya flushed, because even without knowing what exactly Rui had heard, or how much, the man had certainly formed his own, correct, conclusions.

"And this Mizuki is searching your database," Toya bulldozed on, trying to cover his own embarrassment.

"Correct, and I imagine it won't be long before we have what we need. There is one more thing, Toya, and I hope you don't mind that I took the liberty of… canvassing your rooms in the short time I had while Shinonome conversed with the two of you–"

"I do mind," Toya interjected bluntly.

"Regardless," Rui continued, waving his complaint aside, "you may find something… interesting in the bottom of the third drawer."

Toya frowned, and only frowned harder when Rui's eyes danced with amusement. Eyes that were drawn to the tablet by a notification.

"Go arm yourself," Rui said, positively grinning now, with the sort of madness unique to a certain type of unhinged brilliance. "The game, as one says, is afoot."

 

- - -

 

Akito spluttered awake, jarred into an unpleasant consciousness. Again. He coughed, shaking his head in a futile attempt to dispel the water.

"Awake, Princess?"

"Fuck off," Akito growled halfheartedly. The answering blow was anything but, driving the breath out of him as his back slammed against the steel beam he was secured to.

He wasn't sure how long it'd been since they'd taken him, but this was his third wet and rude awakening. Blindfolded, he had no way of tracking time, even if there'd been a window to the outdoor world. He was hungry but not faint, so it couldn't be more than a few hours. His hands were cuffed behind him around some pipe, pulling uncomfortably at his arms and shoulders whether he stood or sat. Another pair of cuffs linked his ankles, although with the way his leg was throbbing, he doubted he'd run far even without the hobble. His unconscious body had settled on his knees, and Akito struggled to maneuver himself as upright as he could.

He'd heard them take photos. When he was not quite conscious first, and then again after they'd dragged him roughly to his feet 'for a proper photo-shoot, pretty boy'.

He wished they'd stop calling him that.

"See, I think you're a lying brat," his captor was saying. Akito hadn't noticed him speaking at first. His head was ringing with a fuzzy silence that concerned him in a vague, persistent way. This guy hadn't been one of the three who'd crashed his place. He figured there were at least another two or three guys, probably more. Didn't take a genius to figure out Akito was strung up here as bait.

"Your precious Toya didn't leave. Maybe that note was real, maybe it was from last week, but he'll be back. And when he does get back, he'll have… a surprise."

"I told ya. He left. That chick scared him off," Akito spat, biting out each word like it pained him. "You were too late. Should've–urk!"

"Did I say you could speak? I didn't think so."

"Yeah? 'Cause you're giving your evil guy monologue?" Akito flinched, knowing he'd earned himself another beating.

Instead, the evil guy chuckled. Not a proper villain chuckle, but close enough to be ridiculous.

And then Akito grunted as something hard and cold slammed into his face.

Fuck that hurt.

"`Evil guy'? And if I'm evil, what does that make your Toya?"

"Get his name out of your filthy mouth," Akito growled, head ringing.

"Toya? That name? You don't like hearing your lover's name? Pity, because we'll be inviting Toya here very soon."

Akito seethed, willing himself to shut the fuck up. His face was throbbing, and something warm and wet trickled down his cheek. He wasn't crying, the water in his hair was still cold, it didn't take a genius to guess it was blood.

"Nothing to say to that? When we've barely hurt you, and your sweet, little Toya's killed… I wonder, did you ever ask him how many? Go on, answer."

"Fuck you."

"Tsk, wrong answer. But I'm feeling generous today. The answer… Well. You called me evil? If so, the only word for him is… monster. Does that frighten you? Living with a cold blooded killer… taking his life once wouldn't pay a tenth of his debt."

The truth was, Akito both didn't want to know, and he could guess. The four turbulent years he'd spent at home… knowing his father's men were killing people on his, Akito's, behalf made him feel dirty. They were good at it too.

If they were here, these chumps would get their brains blown out in seconds.

But even if he could, Akito wasn't desperate enough to beg for their help. For his father's help. At least, not yet.

And he hoped to god that when Toya came, he wasn't stupid enough to show up alone.

When? If. He shouldn't.

Who the fuck would he even bring?

A sinking feeling in his chest: Ena.

Well, he owed her enough as it was. Not like one more piece to that pile of debt would make it any better or worse.

God, and this guy wouldn't stop talking.

"Shut up already," Akito muttered. "I keep telling you he's gone."

"And that's bad news for you, princess," a new voice said. Akito tensed as footsteps accompanied the approaching voice. Fingers roughly tilted his chin up and he flinched away, slamming his head into the metal beam again. His vision exploded white, and words seemed fuzzy.

"If what you say is true, then we have no more use for you. Normally we'd just dump your body, but you're a feisty pretty face and there's people who pay good, hard cash for that."

Akito stilled, his skin suddenly numb, a shiver running down his spine, ice sloughing down his back, colder than the water he'd been repeatedly doused with.

"So that's got your attention, has it?"

"Shut up," Akito said, cursing himself for how weak his voice was. He swallowed dryly. "Shut up!"

"Not his face," he heard, before doubling over from a blow to the stomach, and then crumpling to the ground at the sharp crack of something striking his legs.

Fuck it hurt.

Let me go, a small voice in his head pleaded. Just let me go. He couldn't let that voice out.

He squeezed his eyes shut, tears wetting the blindfold. It hurt to breathe, but he had to try. It hurt. Everything hurt. Like it used to. Each breath was shaky. Difficult.

Let me go. I wanna go home.

Such a young voice.

He whimpered when a hand closed roughly around his shoulder and hauled him to his feet. He tried to twist out of that grasp but all he got for his troubles was a hard shake and a blow to the chest. The click of a camera, and then the hand was gone, and he crashed to the ground without the bruising support. His arms wrenched behind him was the only thing that saved his face from the concrete.

Let go of me!

There were whispered instructions, but Akito's brain was too foggy to pick out the words. He shoved that voice down, trying to focus on the present.

Damn, whatever Toya had done for these fuckers to hate him that much… Akito could guess. But it wasn't like he could've let Toya alone. A whore house kid. Just another brat.

How many people had Toya killed?

He didn't want to know. The coffee. Toya loved coffee. Akito hadn't drank much coffee before him, but now the mornings always smelled of coffee, and sometimes the afternoons too. He liked listening to music. Fancy music, pianos and violins and orchestras. The stray cat that'd show up at the store, and sometimes follow them home, winding between Toya's legs. He loved animals. Toya's smile was always so gentle.

Monster. Cold blooded killer.

That wasn't fair, he'd just been another kid trying to survive.

All the aunties loved the new, quiet boy who'd moved in with Akito. What a kind, thoughtful boy, they'd said.

Monster.

At least Toya'd never hurt someone for fun. He'd just been trying to survive.

What a good child, always so helpful, always ready to do anything we ask.

That was right. It was just how things worked. Did what you had to do to live. There was blood on Akito's hands too. Plenty of it, even if he hadn't done it himself. His sister had swore it, the moment she'd laid eyes on him for the first time in years. Every single person who'd ever hurt Akito would pay. And they paid in blood.

The fogginess in his head was spreading. Unconsciousness beckoned. Might as well pass the time as best he could. He'd get another rude awakening soon. Only way he'd get his mind off the sharp, stabbing pain in his leg.

 

-

 

Trepidation dogged Toya as they drove up to the rendezvous. His heart kept dropping in his chest, as if the danger was growing each time. This was his fault. A job left half done.

He reached for the gun in his pocket, and the touch of hard metal calmed him. There had been a veritable armoury stashed in their clothes chest, outfitted with attachments that Toya was sure would be useful in different circumstances. He'd slipped the thin vest under his shirt, but had abandoned the rest. He appreciated the effort Rui had put into the collection. Right now, he needed simplicity. Reassurance.

"Nervous?" Rui asked, sensing Toya's discomfort.

"No. I'm worried about Akito," Toya said, brows creasing. It was the truth.

"As expected," Rui mused as they pulled to a stop behind a warehouse of sorts.

A girl with pink hair was waiting for them. She grinned and waved at them, jogging over at an easy pace as the two men got out of the car. This girl, with ribbons in her hair and wearing a dress lined in lace, had to be Mizuki. Toya… stared.

"So you're Lil Bro's pal," she said.

Toya frowned. This was definitely Mizuki. She was probably older than him.

"You beat us here," Rui said, ignoring her comment.

"Rude." Mizuki made a face at Rui and crossed her arms. The frills on her shoulders fluttered with the motion. "Aren't you gonna at least introduce us?"

"I'm Toya. You must be Mizuki," Toya cut in. "Thank you for your assistance."

Mizuki was first taken aback, and then a smile spread across her face. "Aw, you're so polite! That's so cute. Rui briefed you on the way here, correct? You'll have to do most of the heavy lifting, Lil Bro's buddy, but from your records you'll have no problem with that. Rui's job will be securing your path. I'll have to hang back a bit, but don't worry–I'll keep an eye on you!"

Mizuki winked and hefted what appeared to be a violin case higher on her shoulder. So she was a sniper.

"Any sign of Junior?" Rui asked.

All signs of mirth melted from Mizuki's face. "No, but I'm sure this is the right place. I traced the car as far as it would go. So either he's still in the car, or he's in there."

There was a plain looking building, a squat two floors, grey walls, probably awaiting demolition. There was no easy approach that'd let them in unseen. Not in the afternoon light.

"Sure you don't wanna wait until evening?" Mizuki asked. "It's gonna be tough–"

"No. No more waiting. If Akito's in there, I'm getting him out. It's my fault he's there."

Mizuki sighed and met Rui's eyes, but Rui just lifted one shoulder in a shrug. "They might expect him later, but they don't expect anyone yet," he said.

"Yeah, about that…" Mizuki frowned, and then pulled out a tablet. She angled it towards Rui, clearly not intending on showing Toya. Rui frowned as well, followed by a deep exhale.

"When was this?" Rui asked.

"About ten minutes ago. The tablet is clever. They can remote wipe it and change the display as needed. No need to come back for… updates."

"Please show me," Toya interrupted. "If Akito was meant to be bait, then that is the hook. Please show it to me, I don't wish to be uninformed."

The two of them shared a silent conversation, and Toya watched as Rui angled his head towards him, followed by Mizuki's shrug of acceptance.

"That's true enough," Mizuki said, handing the tablet to Rui. "He's all yours."

"Don't get a hot head," Rui warned him as he rapidly tapped the screen. He beckoned Toya closer, his mouth tightening.

That, Toya knew, as he stared down at the screen, was advice he'd find difficult to heed.

"And then some instructions for you to go to a third place, unarmed and alone of course, but it's a decoy address as we expected," Rui said, turning the screen off once it was clear Toya had gotten a good look. "I'm quite relieved I left the drone, this would have been much harder to manage if there were only the cameras."

"Yup, you did good on that one!" Mizuki chirped, jarringly cheerful. "So now that we're all on the same page–time for a rescue mission? Hey, you still with us, Lil Bro–"

"Please call me Toya. And yes, I am listening."

"Sorry, sorry. Right, you've got your work cut out for you. Doesn't look like they've got eyes outside, not yet at least. A couple guys left but aren't back yet. I… can kinda guess where they are."

"How many inside?" Rui interrupted.

"No clue," Mizuki admitted. "Looks like some sorta temporary headquarters thing, since their last one was…" She trailed off, glancing nervously at Toya. "Anyway! They've gotta have some security cameras if it's a mid-term thing."

"Cameras I can deal with," Rui said, waving away that particular concern. "The rest's up to you, kid– Toya."

The image of Akito blindfolded and struggling to stand burned in his mind.

Don't get a hot head.

That was how mistakes were made.

He nodded.

"Thank you both," he said, looking at each of them in turn. "Your help has been indispensible."

Mizuki actually cooed while Rui sketched a bow.

"Junior's safety is our primary concern," he said, serious and somber. It was somewhat undermined by Mizuki clapping her hands together in glee.

"You're so well behaved! Oh, I so want to hug you but you hitmen type are always touchy about touch. I guess I'll put a rain check on that–"

"Mizuki, I believe we were in the middle of something," Rui cut her off with a long suffering sigh, and an apologetic look towards Toya.

"You're no fun," Mizuki huffed. "But alright, let's do this. Just remember, rain check!"

"Akito comes first," Toya said, narrowing his eyes. "Nothing else matters."

"And there you have it," Rui said, gesturing graciously to Mizuki. "Akito comes first. You and I, we have some groundwork to do. Did you bring what I asked?"

"Did you think I didn't?" Mizuki countered, reaching into a pocket hidden in the folds of her skirt. She grabbed Toya's hand and dropped something in his palm before he could react. He was suddenly very glad she was on his side. She winked, like she'd read his mind, and tossed the same something to Rui who snatched it out of the air.

Toya looked at the earpiece in his hand. It seemed ordinary enough–

"It's nothing special," Rui admitted, fitting it into his ear. "Just a few tweaks so it can't be intercepted, extra long battery life, a clear signal even through concrete…"

"Yeah, yeah, we get it, you're a genius inventor, the next Edison, all that. Now weren't you saying we had something to do?" Mizuki had grabbed Rui's hand and was tugging him along. "We're going on ahead–we'll let you know when it's as clear as we can get it!"

Toya watched, slightly speechless, as Mizuki waved at him cheerfully while leaving.

Akito came first.

Processing the past ten minutes came after.

 

- - -

 

Akito woke to the sound of gunfire.

Toya.

His consciousness jerked awake, clinging to that one thought, but his body was slow and sluggish.

Chaos erupted. Someone screamed that someone was down, which made Akito smile in vicious glee. He tried to stand but his leg gave out with a sharp complaint of pain that left him gasping for breath.

"Where the fuck is that coming from!?"

"Shit, outside?"

"There's–urk!"

Served him right.

A crowd of footsteps thundered down the stairs, and Akito realised with a sinking feeling that there were far more people than he'd thought. He could barely pick out words in the cacaphony of voices, of panic, of anger, of pain, of death, but it seemed that for the moment, he'd been forgotten.

And then:

"What the–it's him!"

Toya.

"Toya!" The name tore itself from Akito's throat with a mind of its own, but it barely made a dent in the chaos.

Fuck, he wished he could see.

The sudden, unmistakable feeling of a gun pressed to his head. Oh. He probably shouldn't have yelled.
